Morning.name: Watch sunrise from Trocadéro with Eiffel Tower views
Morning.description: Arrive at the Trocadéro esplanade just before dawn when Paris is still asleep. As the sun crests the horizon, the Eiffel Tower transforms from silhouette to gilded iron against pastel skies. The empty marble plaza gives you unobstructed views and perfect photos without the usual crowd jostling. Bring a thermos of café—the city awakens beautifully from here.
Morning.address: Champ de Mars, 5 Av. Anatole France, 75007 Paris

Morning.name: Early climb of Sacré-Cœur for a quiet Montmartre moment
Morning.description: The 270 steps to Sacré-Cœur reward early risers with Paris sprawling silently below. Before tourist buses arrive, the white Romano-Byzantine basilica belongs to you and a few locals walking dogs. Inside, flickering candles and morning light through stained glass create an atmosphere of genuine contemplation. The free funicular runs from 6am if your legs protest.
Morning.address: 35 Rue du Chevalier de la Barre, 75018 Paris

Morning.name: Croissant + café crème at Café de Flore
Morning.description: Sink into the same red velvet banquettes where Sartre debated Beauvoir and Picasso sketched on napkins. Yes, the prices are eye-watering (€8 for coffee), but you're paying for literary history served with your flaky, butter-laminated croissant. Sit outside on the terrace to watch Saint-Germain wake up, or inside for the unchanged Art Deco warmth. A quintessential Paris morning.

Morning.name: Fresh baguette from Poilâne bakery
Morning.description: Follow your nose to this legendary bakery founded in 1932. Skip the baguettes (sacrilege!)—Poilâne is famous for their massive sourdough miche, baked in wood-fired ovens. The butter cookies (punitions) and apple tarts are excellent detours. Ask for a peek at the basement ovens if the staff aren't overwhelmed. Buy extra; it freezes beautifully.

Morning.name: Visit Sainte-Chapelle when the sun hits the stained glass
Morning.description: Book the first morning slot when eastern sunlight blazes through 1,113 stained-glass panels, transforming this Gothic chapel into a kaleidoscope of ruby, sapphire, and gold. Built in just seven years for King Louis IX to house Christ's Crown of Thorns, Sainte-Chapelle is medieval architecture at its most audacious—walls dissolve into 15 meters of luminous glass, held together by the slenderest stone ribs. The upper chapel steals the breath; the lower chapel (often missed) features painted ceilings and the original floor tiles. On sunny mornings, it's the most beautiful interior in Paris.

Morning.name: Walk through the Louvre courtyard before opening
Morning.description: The I.M. Pei pyramid surrounded by empty Cour Napoléon at dawn is a photographer's dream. Without crowds obscuring the geometry, you can appreciate how modern glass plays against Renaissance stone. Security opens the courtyard before the museum—perfect for those not planning to go inside. The reflecting pools mirror the sky in golden hour.

Morning.name: Breakfast picnic in Luxembourg Gardens
Morning.description: Gather croissants from a nearby bakery, fresh fruit from a marché, and excellent coffee from Coutume Café. Claim one of the iconic green metal chairs near the Medici Fountain as morning light filters through the chestnut trees. Joggers pass, toddlers sail model boats in the octagonal basin, and you have Paris's most perfect free breakfast spot.
Morning.address: Rue de Médicis, Rue de Vaugirard, 75006 Paris

Morning.name: Morning stroll along Canal Saint-Martin
Morning.description: Before the brunch crowds descend, the Canal Saint-Martin belongs to joggers, dog-walkers, and the clink of espresso cups. Start at Place de la République and walk north along the tree-shaded Quai de Valmy, watching the 19th-century swing bridges creak open for passing boats. Pause at the double locks near Hôtel du Nord (yes, from the 1938 film) where water cascades between levels. Stop for exceptional coffee at Ten Belles or Café Craft, browse the vintage shops on Rue Beaurepaire, then cross to Quai de Jemmapes for the iconic view of iron footbridges stretching into the distance. This is the Paris of young Parisians—creative, unhurried, and mercifully free of monuments.
Morning.address: Quai de Jemmapes & Quai de Valmy, 75010 Paris

Morning.name: See Notre-Dame from Pont de l'Archevêché
Morning.description: The Pont de l'Archevêché offers the most iconic view of Notre-Dame's flying buttresses and Gothic apse reflected in the Seine. Morning light paints the limestone golden while the cathedral's spire—now restored after the fire—pierces the Parisian sky. Stand at the bridge's center for symmetrical shots, or wander to the gardens behind for quieter angles among the chestnut trees.

Morning.name: Browse bouquinistes (bookstalls) along the Seine
Morning.description: These green boxes have lined the Seine since the 16th century—the world's largest open-air bookshop. Most open around 10am when weather permits. Look for vintage posters, antique maps, and first editions among the tourist trinkets. The stalls between Pont Marie and Pont de Sully are most authentic; the Notre-Dame side more touristy.
Morning.address: Quais de la Seine (Rive Droite & Gauche), 75001–75006 Paris

Morning.name: Explore Place des Vosges in Le Marais
Morning.description: Explore explore place des vosges in le marais.

Morning.name: Fresh produce shopping at Marché Bastille
Morning.description: Relax in fresh produce shopping at marché bastille.

Morning.name: Visit the Rodin Museum gardens before the crowds
Morning.description: Experience visit the rodin museum gardens before the crowds.

Morning.name: Watch the changing of the guard at Hôtel des Invalides
Morning.description: Take in watch the changing of the guard at hôtel des invalides.

Morning.name: Coffee at Boot Café (tiny but perfect)
Morning.description: Savor coffee at boot café (tiny but perfect).
Morning.address: 19 Rue du Pont aux Choux, 75003 Paris

Morning.name: Explore Rue Cler market street
Morning.description: Relax in explore rue cler market street.

Morning.name: Tour Opéra Garnier in the quiet morning hours
Morning.description: Experience tour opéra garnier in the quiet morning hours.

Morning.name: Take in Place Vendôme’s early stillness
Morning.description: Explore take in place vendôme’s early stillness.

Morning.name: Explore the covered passages (Galerie Vivienne, Passage des Panoramas)
Morning.description: Discover explore the covered passages (galerie vivienne, passage des panoramas).

Morning.name: Stop at Pierre Hermé for morning pastries
Morning.description: Savor stop at pierre hermé for morning pastries.

Morning.name: Morning mass at Saint-Sulpice
Morning.description: Savor morning mass at saint-sulpice.

Morning.name: Early peek at Musée d'Orsay's clock tower views
Morning.description: Head straight to the 5th floor when doors open at 9:30am to discover Orsay's secret treasure: the giant transparent clock face that once told time to railway passengers below. Stand behind the frosted glass numerals for a surreal view of the Seine and Tuileries through Roman numerals, the Sacré-Cœur floating in the distance. The Impressionist galleries nearby are quietest now, letting you commune with Monet and Van Gogh in relative peace before the crowds surge upward.
Morning.address: 1 Rue de la Légion d'Honneur, 75007 Paris

Morning.name: Visit Shakespeare & Company before the line builds
Morning.description: Capture visit shakespeare & company before the line builds.

Midday.name: Louvre highlights: Mona Lisa, Winged Victory, Venus de Milo
Midday.description: Skip the pyramid queue by entering through the underground Carrousel du Louvre mall or the quieter Porte des Lions. Start with the Winged Victory of Samothrace crowning the Denaon staircase—her windswept drapery is best seen climbing toward her. The Mona Lisa draws crowds to Salle 711, but Leonardo's other works nearby (St. John the Baptist, Virgin of the Rocks) offer intimate viewing. Venus de Milo stands serene in the Greek antiquities wing. Download the free Louvre app for the 90-minute 'Masterpieces' trail, and consider Wednesday or Friday evenings (until 9:45pm) when galleries empty out and soft lighting transforms the experience.

Midday.name: Musée d’Orsay Impressionist collection
Midday.description: Discover musée d’orsay impressionist collection.
Midday.address: 1 Rue de la Légion d'Honneur, 75007 Paris

Midday.name: Centre Pompidou modern art
Midday.description: The inside-out building that scandalized 1970s Paris now houses Europe's largest modern art collection. Exposed pipes, ducts, and escalators in primary colors wrap the exterior like a mad scientist's factory—the real shock is how well it works. Inside, Picasso, Kandinsky, Dalí, and Warhol share space with boundary-pushing contemporary installations. Ride the caterpillar-like exterior escalator to the 6th floor for panoramic rooftop views rivaling any in Paris. The plaza below buzzes with street performers, and the design library and cinema offer deeper dives for the curious.

Midday.name: Explore Musée Picasso
Midday.description: Discover explore musée picasso.

Midday.name: Visit Musée de l’Orangerie for Monet’s water lilies
Midday.description: Discover visit musée de l’orangerie for monet’s water lilies.

Midday.name: Pantheon history and views from the dome
Midday.description: Beneath the Panthéon's neoclassical dome lie France's greatest minds—Voltaire, Rousseau, Marie Curie, Victor Hugo—in a crypt that hums with gravitas. Upstairs, Foucault's original pendulum still swings, proving Earth's rotation. The real reward comes from April–October when 206 spiral steps lead to the colonnade encircling the dome. At the top, Paris unfurls 360 degrees: the Latin Quarter's zinc rooftops, Luxembourg Gardens, Montmartre in the distance. Book timed dome access online—slots fill fast on clear days.

Midday.name: Explore Musée Carnavalet (Paris history)
Midday.description: Paris tells its own story in this free museum occupying two Renaissance mansions in the Marais. Roman artifacts, Louis XIV's furnishings, Proust's cork-lined bedroom, and rooms salvaged from demolished Parisian interiors create an intimate journey through the city's layers. Recently renovated with modern museography. Allow 2 hours minimum.

Midday.name: Petit Palais (free and gorgeous)
Midday.description: This often-overlooked Beaux-Arts gem across from the Grand Palais houses an impressive permanent collection—completely free. Rembrandt, Monet, Cézanne, and Courbet share space with ancient Greek and Medieval art. The interior garden café under the glass dome is reason enough to visit. A secret weapon for rainy days.

Midday.name: Grande Mosquée de Paris tea garden
Midday.description: Experience grande mosquée de paris tea garden.
Midday.address: 2bis Pl. du Puits de l’Ermite, 75005 Paris

Midday.name: Walk the Champs-Élysées from Place de la Concorde
Midday.description: Wander walk the champs-élysées from place de la concorde.

Midday.name: Visit Palais Royal & its striped columns
Midday.description: Take in visit palais royal & its striped columns.

Midday.name: Explore Hôtel de Ville’s exhibitions
Midday.description: Paris's City Hall is a Renaissance Revival palace hiding one of the city's best-kept secrets: world-class free exhibitions in its sumptuous Salons. While tourists photograph the ornate facade, slip inside to discover photography retrospectives, historical archives, and contemporary art displayed beneath gilded ceilings and crystal chandeliers. The building itself stuns—rebuilt after the 1871 Commune fire, its ceremonial rooms rival Versailles in grandeur. Check the current exhibition online before visiting; themes range from Paris urbanism to international photojournalism. The esplanade outside hosts seasonal attractions: an ice rink in winter, beach volleyball in summer.
Midday.address: Pl. de l’Hôtel de Ville, 75004 Paris

Midday.name: Visit the Conciergerie (Marie Antoinette’s prison)
Midday.description: Capture visit the conciergerie (marie antoinette’s prison).

Midday.name: See Les Invalides and Napoleon’s Tomb
Midday.description: Discover see les invalides and napoleon’s tomb.

Midday.name: Tour the Musée de Cluny (medieval treasures)
Midday.description: Savor tour the musée de cluny (medieval treasures).

Midday.name: Explore Saint-Eustache church near Les Halles
Midday.description: Take in explore saint-eustache church near les halles.

Midday.name: Stroll Rue Montorgueil for gourmet shops
Midday.description: Discover stroll rue montorgueil for gourmet shops.

Midday.name: Tour Musée des Arts Décoratifs
Midday.description: Admire tour musée des arts décoratifs.

Midday.name: Palais de Tokyo contemporary art space
Midday.description: Relax in palais de tokyo contemporary art space.

Midday.name: Picnic at Champ de Mars under Eiffel Tower
Midday.description: Immerse in picnic at champ de mars under eiffel tower.
Midday.address: Champ de Mars, 5 Av. Anatole France, 75007 Paris

Midday.name: Explore Musée Jacquemart-André
Midday.description: Savor explore musée jacquemart-andré.

Midday.name: Musée Marmottan Monet (hidden gem)
Midday.description: Take in musée marmottan monet (hidden gem).

Midday.name: Walk Boulevard Saint-Germain
Midday.description: This legendary Left Bank artery pulses with the ghosts of Sartre, de Beauvoir, and the existentialist revolution. Start at the medieval church of Saint-Germain-des-Prés, then stroll past the twin literary cafés—Les Deux Magots and Café de Flore—where ideas that shaped the 20th century were scribbled on napkins. Browse the antiquarian bookshops near Odéon, duck into the Art Deco brasserie Lipp for a glimpse of its celebrity clientele, and end at the Seine with views of Notre-Dame. The boulevard's Haussmann architecture, designer boutiques, and intellectual heritage make it quintessentially Parisian—best enjoyed slowly, with espresso stops.

Afternoon.name: Stroll the banks of Île Saint-Louis
Afternoon.description: Step onto this slender island behind Notre-Dame and Paris fades to a whisper. No monuments compete for attention—just 17th-century hôtels particuliers with iron balconies, streets named after French provinces (Anjou, Bourbon, Orléans), and quays where lovers dangle feet over the Seine. Walk the full perimeter on the lower embankments for unobstructed water views and Notre-Dame's Gothic profile rising ahead. Stop at Berthillon for legendary ice cream, browse the antique shops on Rue Saint-Louis en l'Île, then claim a bench on the island's western tip as the sun drops behind the Pont Neuf. This is Paris distilled to its romantic essence.

Afternoon.name: Ice cream at Berthillon
Afternoon.description: Since 1954, this Île Saint-Louis institution has served what many consider France's finest ice cream. The sorbets (wild strawberry, passion fruit) are legendary; salted caramel and praline dominate among the glaces. Lines can be brutal—try the nearby shops that resell Berthillon scoops with shorter waits. Closed Monday and Tuesday.

Afternoon.name: Walk along Rue des Rosiers in Le Marais
Afternoon.description: Admire walk along rue des rosiers in le marais.

Afternoon.name: Tea at Angelina (famous hot chocolate)
Afternoon.description: This Belle Époque tearoom on Rue de Rivoli has served its legendarily thick 'l'Africain' hot chocolate since 1903. The whipped cream comes separately; the Mont-Blanc chestnut vermicelli dessert is their signature. Yes, it's expensive and tourist-heavy, but the gilded mirrors and ceiling frescoes transport you to another era. Worth one visit.

Afternoon.name: Visit Marché d’Aligre flea market
Afternoon.description: Experience visit marché d’aligre flea market.

Afternoon.name: Take photos at Pont Alexandre III
Afternoon.description: Take in take photos at pont alexandre iii.

Afternoon.name: Relax at Parc des Buttes-Chaumont
Afternoon.description: Experience relax at parc des buttes-chaumont.

Afternoon.name: Browse Saint-Ouen flea market (weekends)
Afternoon.description: The world's largest antiques market sprawls across 7 hectares with 15 distinct marchés, each with its own character—from high-end Art Deco dealers in Marché Serpette to junk-heap treasures in Marché Malik. Come early Saturday or Sunday for the best finds: vintage Hermès scarves, 1950s cafe chairs, architectural salvage, antique maps, and curiosities you didn't know existed. Haggling is expected (start at 30% off), and even if you buy nothing, the people-watching is world-class. Grab a crêpe from a street vendor and lose yourself in the labyrinth—serious collectors budget half a day.
Afternoon.address: Marché aux Puces de Saint-Ouen, 93400 Saint-Ouen

Afternoon.name: Visit Musée Zadkine sculpture garden
Afternoon.description: Hidden behind a wooden gate on Rue d'Assas, this intimate museum preserves the studio and garden where Russian-born sculptor Ossip Zadkine lived and worked from 1928 until his death in 1967. Cubist bronzes and marble figures stand among climbing roses, wisteria, and ancient trees—a secret oasis steps from the Luxembourg Gardens. The small cottage studio remains as he left it, tools scattered mid-project. Zadkine's masterpiece, 'The Destroyed City' (a cast stands in Rotterdam), was conceived here. Free entry, rarely crowded, and impossibly romantic—this is the Paris that rewards those who wander off the obvious path.

Afternoon.name: Explore Rue Mouffetard market street
Afternoon.description: Sample explore rue mouffetard market street.

Afternoon.name: Have a crepe in Montparnasse
Afternoon.description: Explore have a crepe in montparnasse.

Afternoon.name: Visit Fondation Louis Vuitton (modern architecture)
Afternoon.description: Savor visit fondation louis vuitton (modern architecture).

Afternoon.name: Relax in Parc de Belleville’s city views
Afternoon.description: Immerse in relax in parc de belleville’s city views.

Afternoon.name: Browse Galeries Lafayette rooftop terrace
Afternoon.description: Savor browse galeries lafayette rooftop terrace.
Afternoon.address: 25 Rue de la Chaussée d'Antin, 75009 Paris

Afternoon.name: Musée des Arts et Métiers (science/innovation)
Afternoon.description: Housed in a medieval priory, this cabinet of wonders traces human ingenuity from the Renaissance to the Space Age. Foucault's original pendulum swings in the former church nave, proving Earth's rotation as it has since 1851. Around it: Lavoisier's chemistry lab, the Lumière brothers' cinematograph, early automobiles, and Blériot's plane that crossed the Channel. The collection feels like exploring a steampunk inventor's attic—less polished than the Science Museum, more atmospheric, utterly French. Kids love the hands-on experiments; adults marvel at the craftsmanship of scientific instruments as art.

Afternoon.name: Explore Parc André Citroën’s hot air balloon ride
Afternoon.description: Savor explore parc andré citroën’s hot air balloon ride.

Evening.name: Sunset at Trocadéro with Eiffel Tower sparkle after dark
Evening.description: The marble esplanade offers the most iconic Eiffel Tower view in Paris. Arrive at golden hour with a bottle of wine from a nearby caviste. As twilight deepens, wait for the hourly sparkle show—20,000 lights dancing for five magical minutes. The crowd gasps every time. Stay for the second sparkle; the first draws spectators away.
Evening.address: Champ de Mars, 5 Av. Anatole France, 75007 Paris

Evening.name: Golden views from Pont des Arts
Evening.description: The Pont des Arts footbridge delivers Paris's most romantic golden hour panorama: the Louvre on one side, the Institut de France's green dome on the other, and the Seine flowing beneath your feet as the sky turns amber. Once famous for its love locks (now removed for safety), the bridge remains a magnet for painters, musicians, and couples sharing wine at sunset. Arrive 30 minutes before sunset to claim a spot on the wooden slats, and stay as the city's monuments light up one by one. Bring a picnic blanket and a bottle—street vendors sell wine nearby.

Evening.name: Climb Arc de Triomphe at sunset
Evening.description: Admire climb arc de triomphe at sunset.

Evening.name: Watch street performers at Place du Tertre, Montmartre
Evening.description: As the day-trippers drain from Montmartre's hilltop square, a different energy takes over. Portrait artists pack up their easels and buskers emerge—accordion players, jazz guitarists, fire performers when the light fades. Grab a glass of wine from a terrace café, find a spot on the worn cobblestones, and watch the square transform from tourist snapshot into genuine bohemian theater. The performers here have stories; the best moments come when the crowd thins and an impromptu collaboration breaks out between musicians.

Evening.name: Twilight stroll along the Seine
Evening.description: Discover twilight stroll along the seine.

Evening.name: Seine dinner cruise
Evening.description: Glide past illuminated monuments while savoring French cuisine and champagne. Bateaux Parisiens and Marina de Paris offer refined dining; the food is surprisingly excellent given floating kitchen constraints. Dress code applies to upscale cruises. For tighter budgets, simpler cruises offer equally stunning views with less formality.

Evening.name: Jazz night at Le Caveau de la Huchette
Evening.description: Swing dancers have packed this medieval cellar since 1946. The vaulted stone caves host nightly jazz, bebop, and swing with irresistible energy. Cover charge includes first drink. No reservations—just queue and descend into Paris's most authentic jazz experience. Dancing lessons for beginners on quieter nights. Pure magic.

Evening.name: Apéro (pre-dinner drink) at Canal Saint-Martin
Evening.description: Join the Parisian ritual of l'apéro along the tree-lined Canal Saint-Martin, where locals gather on cobblestone quays with wine, cheese, and easy conversation as the sun dips low. Grab a bottle from nearby Le Verre Volé, pick up charcuterie from a fromagerie, and claim a spot on the iron footbridges or canal-side steps. Watch the vintage swing bridges creak open for passing boats while hipsters strum guitars and couples share picnic blankets. This is the relaxed, unscripted Paris that tourists rarely find.
Evening.address: Quai de Jemmapes & Quai de Valmy, 75010 Paris

Evening.name: Montparnasse Tower panoramic view
Evening.description: Parisians call it ugly, but the 210-meter observation deck offers something the Eiffel Tower can't: a view of the Eiffel Tower. Sunset timing is ideal; stay for the hourly sparkle. The 56th floor champagne bar adds romance. Less crowded and cheaper than Eiffel Tower summit. The joke goes: best view in Paris because you can't see Montparnasse.

Evening.name: Watch Eiffel Tower sparkle from Champ de Mars
Evening.description: Relax in watch eiffel tower sparkle from champ de mars.
Evening.address: Champ de Mars, 5 Av. Anatole France, 75007 Paris

Evening.name: Attend a cooking class
Evening.description: Immerse in attend a cooking class.

Evening.name: See Louvre Pyramid glow after dark
Evening.description: After the museum closes, the Cour Napoléon becomes a magical theater of light. The pyramid glows from within like a giant lantern while the Renaissance wings are bathed in warm floodlights. The reflecting pools create perfect mirror images on still evenings. Stay until 10pm when crowds thin and you can photograph the illuminated geometry without tourists. On Wednesdays and Fridays, combine with a late museum visit (open until 9:45pm) for a full evening experience.

Evening.name: Attend an opera or ballet at Opéra Garnier
Evening.description: Take in attend an opera or ballet at opéra garnier.

Evening.name: Try escargots at a traditional brasserie
Evening.description: Admire try escargots at a traditional brasserie.

Evening.name: Enjoy craft cocktails in Pigalle
Evening.description: Enjoy enjoy craft cocktails in pigalle.

LateNight.name: Walk Rue Oberkampf’s lively scene
LateNight.description: Relax in walk rue oberkampf’s lively scene.

LateNight.name: Moonlit Montmartre walk
LateNight.description: After the portrait artists pack up and the tourists retreat, Montmartre reveals its bohemian soul. Begin at Place du Tertre as the last light fades, then wander gaslit streets where Picasso, Van Gogh, and Toulouse-Lautrec once roamed. Descend the quiet Rue de l'Abreuvoir past pink-shuttered houses, pause at the Clos Montmartre vineyard (Paris's only working vineyard), and peer through the garden gate of the Musée de Montmartre. End at Au Lapin Agile, the legendary cabaret hosting artists since 1860, or a wine bar on Rue Lepic. The cobblestones echo differently at night.

LateNight.name: Palais de Tokyo’s late-night hours
LateNight.description: Explore palais de tokyo’s late-night hours.

LateNight.name: Watch Eiffel Tower’s final sparkle at 1 am
LateNight.description: Explore watch eiffel tower’s final sparkle at 1 am.
LateNight.address: Champ de Mars, 5 Av. Anatole France, 75007 Paris

LateNight.name: Sip champagne at Le Bar Hemingway (Ritz)
LateNight.description: Take in sip champagne at le bar hemingway (ritz).

DayTrips_Seasonal.name: Versailles Palace & Gardens
DayTrips_Seasonal.description: Louis XIV's palace of excess takes a full day to appreciate—arrive at 9am sharp via RER C. The Hall of Mirrors dazzles; Marie Antoinette's Hamlet charms. Gardens require a separate ticket on fountain show days (Tuesday, Saturday, Sunday). Pack lunch; on-site restaurants are mediocre. The Petit Trianon offers intimate contrast to the overwhelming main palace.

DayTrips_Seasonal.name: Monet’s Garden in Giverny
DayTrips_Seasonal.description: Immerse in monet’s garden in giverny.

DayTrips_Seasonal.name: Bastille Day fireworks over Eiffel Tower
DayTrips_Seasonal.description: Experience bastille day fireworks over eiffel tower.
DayTrips_Seasonal.address: Champ de Mars, 5 Av. Anatole France, 75007 Paris

HiddenCorners.name: Parc de la Villette’s themed gardens
HiddenCorners.description: Immerse in parc de la villette’s themed gardens.

HiddenCorners.name: Explore Rue Crémieux’s colorful facades
HiddenCorners.description: Capture explore rue crémieux’s colorful facades.

HiddenCorners.name: Discover hidden courtyards in Le Marais
HiddenCorners.description: Discover discover hidden courtyards in le marais.

HiddenCorners.name: Visit the Musée des Plans-Reliefs
HiddenCorners.description: Wander visit the musée des plans-reliefs.

FoodDrink.name: Wine tasting at Les Caves du Louvre
FoodDrink.description: Descend into 17th-century vaulted stone cellars where royal sommeliers once stored wine for the Louvre palace. Today, expert-led tastings guide you through France's legendary wine regions—from Burgundy's silky Pinot Noirs to Champagne's celebratory bubbles. The intimate 'French Wine Exploration' session introduces five wines with cheese pairings, while the 'Create Your Own Wine' workshop lets you blend a personal Bordeaux to take home. The atmospheric candlelit cellars feel worlds away from the tourist bustle above.

FoodDrink.name: Falafel at L’As du Fallafel
FoodDrink.description: Wander falafel at l’as du fallafel.

ParksGardens.name: Jardin des Serres d’Auteuil greenhouses
ParksGardens.description: Enjoy jardin des serres d’auteuil greenhouses.
ParksGardens.address: 3 Av. de la Porte d'Auteuil, 75016 Paris

ParksGardens.name: Square du Vert-Galant on Île de la Cité
ParksGardens.description: Capture square du vert-galant on île de la cité.

ParksGardens.name: Parc de la Légion d’Honneur
ParksGardens.description: Savor parc de la légion d’honneur.
